exercise.title: Evaluating the definite integral of a rational function
Evaluating the definite integral of a linear function

statement.p: Evaluate the definite integral \int_{ } ^ { } ( x + )\, dx .

solution.p:
Each part of this integral can be done separately, and each is a special case of the general rule \displaystyle \int u^n du = \frac{u^{n+1}}{n+1}:
\int_{}^{} ( x + ) dx \amp= \int_{}^{} x\, dx + \int_{}^{} dx \amp= \left( \left. \frac{x^2}{2} \right|_{}^{} \right) + \left( \left. x \right|_{}^{} \right) \amp= \left( \frac{^2}{2} - \frac{^2}{2} \right) + \left( - \right) =

exercise.title: Evaluating the definite integral of a quadratic function

solution.p: Since the function f(x)= - x^2 is even, \int_{-}^{} ( -x^2)\, dx = 2 \int_{0}^{} ( -x^2)\, dx = 2 \left. \left( x - \frac{x^3}{3}\right) \right|_ {0}^{} = 2 \left[ \left( \cdot - \frac{^3}{3}\right) - (0-0) \right] = 2 \frac{}{3} = .

statement.p: Evaluate the definite integral \int_{ } ^ { } \frac { x^2 + } { \sqrt x }\,dx.

solution.p:
To evaluate the definite integral, we need to determine the antiderivative of the formula to be integrated. This can be done term-by-term by rewriting the integral as: \int_{}^{} \frac{{}x^2 + }{\sqrt{x}}\,dx = \int_{}^{} \left( \frac{{}x^2}{\sqrt{x}} + \frac{}{\sqrt{x}} \right)\,dx. Then, we can find the derivative, which is: F(x) = \frac{2}{5}\left(\frac{{}x^3}{\sqrt{x}}\right) - 2()\sqrt{x}. Now, applying the second part of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, we get the value of the definite integral as:
F() - F() &= \frac{2}{5}\left(\frac{{}()^3}{\sqrt{}}\right) + 2()\sqrt{} -\frac{2}{5}\left(\frac{{}()^3}{\sqrt{}}\right) - 2($b1)\sqrt{} &= - &= .

exercise.title: Evaluating the definite integral of a trigonometric function

solution.p:
This integration can be done because we know that the derivative with respect to x of \cos(x) is -\sin(x). So we obtain a -\sin(x) inside the integral, and we can then integrate to obtain \cos(x). Of course, since there isn't a minus sign inside the integral, we'll have to multiply inside and outside by -1 (which doesn't change the value of course):
\int_0^\pi \sin(x)\,dx &= - \int_0^\pi (-\sin(x))\,dx &= - \left( \left. \cos(x) \right|_0^\pi \right) &= - ( \cos(\pi) - \cos(0) ) = - (-1-1) = 2 \cdot =

statement.p: The instantaneous velocity (in meters per minute) of a moving object is given by the function v as pictured in Figure. Assume that on the interval 0 \le t \le 4, v(t) is given by v(t) = -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1, and that on every other interval v is piecewise linear, as shown.

figure.caption: The velocity function of a moving body.

li.p: Determine the exact distance traveled by the object on the time interval 0 \le t \le 4.
What is the object's average velocity on [12,24]?
At what time is the object's acceleration greatest?
Suppose that the velocity of the object is increased by a constant value c for all values of t. What value of c will make the object's total distance traveled on [12,24] be 210 meters?
20 meters.

\displaystyle v_{\operatorname{AVG} [12,24]} = 12.5
meters per minute.
The object's maximum acceleration is 3 meters per minute per minute at the instant t = 2.

Since velocity is positive, distance traveled is the definite integral of velocity. Thus, on [0,4], the total distance, D, is
D = \int_0^4 v(t) \, dt = \int_0^4 \left( -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1 \right) \, dt . By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,
\int_0^4 \left( -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1 \right) \, dt &= \left. \left( -\frac{1}{16}t^4 + \frac{1}{2}t^3 + t \right) \right|_{t=0}^{t=4} &= -\frac{1}{16}4^4 + \frac{1}{2}4^3 + 4 &= 20 , so the distance traveled by the object on [0,4] is 20 meters.

To find the average velocity of the object on [12,24], we first evaluate \int_{12}^{24} v(t) \, dt. To do so, we use the fact that v is piecewise linear and employ standard geometric formulas to determine the value of the integral. The area of the trapezoid formed by v(t) and the vertical line segments at t = 12 and t = 16 is
A_1 = \frac{1}{2}(f(12) + f(16))(4) = 2(9 + 15) = 48 . The area of the rectangle formed by v(t) and the vertical line segments at t = 16 and t = 20 is
A_2 = 4 \cdot 15 = 60 . Finally, the area of the trapezoid formed by v(t) and the vertical line segments at t = 20 and t = 24 is
A_3 = \frac{1}{2}(f(20) + f(24))(4) = 2(15 + 6) = 42 . Thus,
\int_{12}^{24} v(t) \, dt = A_1 + A_2 + A_3 = 48 + 60 + 42 = 150 , from which it follows that
\displaystyle v_{\operatorname{AVG} [12,24]} = \frac{1}{24-12} \int_{12}^{24} v(t) \, dt = \frac{150}{12} = 12.5
meters per minute.

To find where a(t) is greatest, we recall that a(t) = v'(t), so we are seeking the location where the slope of the tangent line to v(t) is maximized on the interval [0,24]. From the graph, there are only two possible intervals where this can occur: 0 \lt t \lt 4 and 12 \lt t \lt 16, as these are both where v is increasing and thus a(t) = v'(t) is positive.

On 12 \lt t \lt 16, a(t) = v'(t) = \frac{3}{2} since this is the slope of the line that forms v(t) on this interval. On 0 \lt t \lt 4, v(t) = -\frac{1}{4}t^3 + \frac{3}{2}t^2 + 1, so a(t) = v'(t) = -\frac{3}{4}t^2 + 3t. We see that a(t) is a quadratic function that opens down, so its maximum occurs at its vertex, which is located where a'(t) = 0. We know that a'(t) = -\frac{3}{2}t + 3, and 0 = -\frac{3}{2}t + 3 implies t = 2. Moreover, a(2) = v'(2) = -\frac{3}{4} \cdot 2^2 + 3(2) = 3. Clearly a(2) = 3 \gt \frac{3}{2}, so the object's maximum acceleration is 3 meters per minute per minute at the instant t = 2.

Let V(t) = v(t) + c be the new velocity function that is the original velocity v increased by c at every time. We want to know the value of c for which total distance traveled on [12,24] is 210 meters. For this to be true, we must have that
210 = \int_{12}^{24} V(t) \, dt = \int_{12}^{24} \left( v(t) + c \right) \, dt . Using the additive property of the definite integral and our earlier work in (b), we can say that
210 = \int_{12}^{24} v(t) \, dt + \int_{12}^{24} c \, dt = 150 + \int_{12}^{24} c \, dt , so
\int_{12}^{24} c \, dt = 60 . Since the function f(t) = c is constant, the integral \int_{12}^{24} c \, dt represents the area of a rectangle 12 units wide and c units tall, so \int_{12}^{24} c \, dt = 12c. Hence,
12c = 60
so c = \frac{60}{12} = 5.

statement.p:
A function f is given piecewise by the formula
f(x) = \begin{cases} -x^2 + 2x + 1, \amp \ \text{if} \ 0 \le x \lt 2 \\ -x + 3, \amp \ \text{if} \ 2 \le x \lt 3 \\ x^2 - 8x + 15, \amp \ \text{if} \ 3 \le x \le 5 \end{cases} .
Determine the exact value of the net signed area enclosed by f and the x-axis on the interval [2,5].
Compute the exact average value of f on [0,5].
Find a formula for a function g on 5 \le x \le 7 so that if we extend the above definition of f so that f(x) = g(x) if 5 \le x \le 7, it follows that \int_0^7 f(x) \, dx = 0.

li.p: \displaystyle f_{\operatorname{AVG} [0,5]} = \frac{1}{2}.
g(x) = f(x) for 0 \le x \lt 5 and g(x) = -\frac{5}{4}(x - 5) on 5 \le x \le 7.

The net signed area enclosed by f and the x-axis on the interval [2,5] is \int_2^5 f(x) \, dx. The figure below shows a graph of f on the interval [0,5]. To calculate the definite integral of f on the interval [2,5], we consider the integrals on the subintervals [2,3] and [3,5]. Doing so and using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,
\int_2^5 f(x) \, dx &= \int_2^3 f(x) \, dx + \int_3^5 f(x) \, dx &= \int_2^3 -x+3 \, dx + \int_3^5 x^2-8x+15 \, dx &= \left. \left( -\frac{1}{2}x^2 + 3x \right)\right|_2^3 + \left. \left( \frac{1}{3}x^3 - 4x^2 + 15x \right)\right|_3^5 &= \left(\frac{9}{2}-4\right) + \left( \frac{50}{3}-18 \right) &= \frac{127}{6} - 22 = -\frac{5}{6} .

Since \int_0^5 f(x) \, dx = \frac{5}{2}, we need a function g that matches f but that is also defined on [5,7] so that \int_5^7 g(x) \, dx = -\frac{5}{2}. To preserve continuity, we will choose a formula for g that also satisfies g(5) = 0. It's natural to pick a linear function whose graph encloses 5/2 units of area, so one that has a slope of 5/4. To check, we compute
\int_5^7 -\frac{5}{4}(x - 5) \, dx &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left. \left(\frac{x^2}{2} - 5x\right) \right|_5^7 &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left( \frac{49-25}{2} - 5(7-5) \right) &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left( 12 - 10 \right) &= -\left(\frac{5}{4}\right) \left( 2 \right) = -\frac{5}{2} . So g defined so that g(x) = f(x) for 0 \le x \lt 5 and g(x) = -\frac{5}{4}(x - 5) on 5 \le x \le 7 has the desired property. A graph of g is shown in the figure below.

statement.p: When an aircraft attempts to climb as rapidly as possible, its climb rate (in feet per minute) decreases as altitude increases, because the air is less dense at higher altitudes. Given below is a table showing performance data for a certain single engine aircraft, giving its climb rate at various altitudes, where c(h) denotes the climb rate of the airplane at an altitude h.

Let a new function called m(h) measure the number of minutes required for a plane at altitude h to climb the next foot of altitude.
Determine a similar table of values for m(h) and explain how it is related to the table above. Be sure to explain the units.
Give a careful interpretation of a function whose derivative is m(h). Describe what the input is and what the output is. Also, explain in plain English what the function tells us.
Determine a definite integral whose value tells us exactly the number of minutes required for the airplane to ascend to 10,000 feet of altitude. Clearly explain why the value of this integral has the required meaning.
Use the Riemann sum M_5 to estimate the value of the integral you found in (c). Include units on your result.

li.p: The antiderivative function tells the total number of minutes it takes for the plane to climb to an altitude of h feet.
It takes the plane aabout M_5 \approx 15.27 minutes.

Since the given climb rate, c(h), is in feet per minute, and the new function, m(h), is measured in minutes per foot, it follows that m(h) is the reciprocal of c(h), so m(h) = \frac{1}{c(h)}. Hence we get the following updated table.

Given an original function, we know that the units on its derivative are ``units of input per unit of output.'' Since the units on m(h) are ``minutes per foot'', it follows that the antiderivative of m(h) should have output units of ``minutes'' since its input units are ``feet''. The antiderivative function should thus tell us the total number of minutes that it takes for the plane to climb to an altitude of h feet.

The number of minutes required for the airplane to ascend to 10{,}000 feet of altitude is given by the definite integral
M = \int_{0}^{10000} m(h) \, dh
since the units on m(h) are ``minutes per foot'' and the units on \triangle h in the corresponding Riemann sum are ``feet'', so when we take the product of quantities with these units, the resulting numerical quantity is measured in minutes.

For the Riemann sum M_5, we have 5 subintervals. Given the original data, this means that we need to evaluate the function at every other known data point. In particular,
\int_{0}^{10000} m(h) \, dh &\approx M_5 &= m(1000) \cdot 2000 + m(3000) \cdot 2000 + m(5000) \cdot 2000 &+ m(7000) \cdot 2000 + m(9000) \cdot 2000 &= \left( \frac{1}{875} + \frac{1}{780} + \frac{1}{685} + \frac{1}{585} + \frac{1}{490} \right) \cdot 2000 &\approx 0.007634980475 \cdot 2000 &\approx 15.27 . Thus, it takes the plane a bit more than 15 minutes to climb to an altitude of 10,000 feet.

statement.p:
In Chapter, we showed that for an object moving along a straight line with position function s(t), the object's average velocity on the interval [a,b] is given by
AV_{[a,b]} = \frac{s(b)-s(a)}{b-a} .

More recently in Chapter, we found that for an object moving along a straight line with velocity function v(t), the object's average value of its velocity function on [a,b] is
\displaystyle v_{\operatorname{AVG} [a,b]} = \frac{1}{b-a} \int_a^b v(t) \, dt .
Are the average velocity on the interval [a,b] and the average value of the velocity function on [a,b] the same thing? Why or why not? Explain.

solution.p:
Yes, AV_{[a,b]} = \displaystyle v_{\operatorname{AVG} [a,b]}. This is true because of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus and the definitions of these two quantities. In particular,
\displaystyle v_{\operatorname{AVG} [a,b]} &= \frac{1}{b-a} \int_a^b v(t) \, dt &= \frac{s(b)-s(a)}{b-a} &= AV_{a,b} . Average velocity can be thought of in two very different ways: one as the change in position divided by change in time, the other as an average of the values of v(t) itself.

statement.p: In Table in Activity, we noted that for x \gt 0, the antiderivative of f(x) = \frac{1}{x} is F(x) = \ln(x). Here we observe that a key difference between f(x) and F(x) is that f is defined for all x \ne 0, while F is only defined for x \gt 0, and see how we can actually define the antiderivative of f for all values of x.

li.p: Suppose that x \lt 0, and let G(x) = \ln(-x). Compute G'(x).
Explain why G is an antiderivative of f for x \lt 0.

Let H(x) = \ln(|x|), and recall that
|x| = \begin{cases} -x, \amp \ \text{if} \ x \lt 0 \\ x, \amp \ \text{if} \ x \ge 0 \end{cases} . Explain why H(x) = G(x) for x \lt 0 and H(x) = F(x) for x \gt 0.
Now discuss why we say that the antiderivative of \frac{1}{x} is \ln(|x|) for all x \ne 0.
G'(x) = \frac{1}{-x} \cdot (-1) = \frac{1}{x}.
Since for those values of x, G'(x) = \frac{1}{x}.
If x \lt 0, then H(x) = \ln(|x|) = \ln(-x) = G(x); if x \gt 0, then H(x) = \ln(|x|) = \ln(x) = F(x).
For x \lt 0, H'(x) = G'(x) = \frac{1}{x}; for x \gt 0, H'(x) = F'(x) = \frac{1}{x} for all x \ne 0.
By the chain rule, G'(x) = \frac{1}{-x} \cdot (-1) = \frac{1}{x}.
G is an antiderivative of f for x \lt 0 since for those values of x, G'(x) = \frac{1}{x}.
If x \lt 0, then H(x) = \ln(|x|) = \ln(-x) = G(x), while if x \gt 0, then H(x) = \ln(|x|) = \ln(x) = F(x).

By considering the cases of x \lt 0 and x \gt 0, we see that for x \lt 0, H'(x) = G'(x) = \frac{1}{x} and for x \gt 0, H'(x) = F'(x) = \frac{1}{x} for all x \ne 0, the derivative of H(x) = \ln(|x|) is \frac{1}{x}, which makes \ln(|x|) the antiderivative of \frac{1}{x}.
